ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Band pruning in ES-HyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Tony, Since you still define the position of the input nodes and ES-HyperNEAT starts to discover the hidden nodes from there, you can still have input nodes

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Tony,

Since you still define the position of the input nodes and ES-Hyp=
erNEAT
starts to discover the hidden nodes from there, you can still have i=
nput
nodes at the borders. The one thing that's a little trickier is gettin=
g
hidden nodes directly at the boundaries (e.g. x=3D-1), because the locati=
on
of a new hidden node is determined by the center of quadtree square. The=

initial square used for the quadtree extraction
normally spans the space f=
rom (-1, -1) to (1, 1), so similarly to what you
suggested you could have a=
n initial square that e.g. spans the space from
(-1.2, -1.2)  to (1.2, 1.2)=
. This way you could have hidden nodes expressed
closer to e.g. x=3D-1. How=
ever, I'm not sure how important it is to be able
to express hidden nodes a=
t exactly those locations and I believe it
probably doesn't hurt the algori=
thm that the hidden node might be expressed
at a slightly different locatio=
n (e.g. -0.9).

One thing that would be different from previously published=
 ES-HyperNEAT
experiments with a domain like Go is that you have a grid-lik=
e setup of
input nodes instead of having inputs in a horizontal line (e.g. =
at y=3D-1). A
typical setup for HyperNEAT for these kind of domains uses mu=
ltiple
different two-dimensional layers of neurons. An example can be found=
 in
this paper: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/gauci_ppsn10.pdf (figure 1)
=

For ES-HyperNEAT it would probably make sense to give the CPPN an
addition=
al input (instead of an additional output as in the HyperNEAT
paper), which=
 would determine if you query connections from the input to
the hidden laye=
r or from the hidden layer to the output layer. This way the
ES-HyperNEAT a=
lgorithm could just be applied to the one weight output
pattern, as in the =
previously published experiments.

Please let me know if this helps or if y=
ou have any other questions about
ES-HyperNEAT. We will also release an upd=
ated version of ES-HyperNEAT
implemented in C# soon.

Sebastian

On Wed, Ap=
r 11, 2012 at 12:29 AM, wilsontg80 <wilsontg@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
>
=
> On second thought, if I'm evolving a 5x5 board evaluator and treat it as
=
> if it is 7x7, then band pruning will remove the excess edge nodes without=

> automatically clobbering the 5x5 edge nodes. I wonder how effective that=

> would be.
>
> Tony
>
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wils=
ontg@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > What I mean is the band pruning seems too rest=
rictive. Suppose a CPPN
> substrate is being pruned for a Go game board eva=
luator. If ideally the
> weights along the board edge should be expressed t=
hey will be removed by
> band pruning. Am I missing something?
> >
> > Tony=

> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > >
=
> > >
> > > Hi Tony, I believe the issue there is with the definition of a =
"band":
> > >
> > > "points that are enclosed by at least two neighbors on =
opposite sides
> (e.g. left and right) with di fferent CPPN activation leve=
ls"
> > >
> > > Note that the points in the outer black region do not have =
_two_
> neighbors of different level on opposite sides, so I believe that i=
s the
> reason they are pruned away. However, it's possible that I'm
> misu=
nderstanding the question, in which case please let me know.
> > >
> > > Re=
garding the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a language through its
> patt=
ern," this idea conveys that of course there is more than one way to
> inte=
rpret the patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose, and any such
> method =
of interpretation is a kind of language. In other words, there might
> be o=
ther perfectly legitimate ways of deciding which connections to express
> f=
rom an infinite-resolution pattern that are different from the method in
> =
the paper (i.e. those would be different "languages" for the CPPN to
> expr=
ess what it wants).
> > >
> > > However, the "language" suggested in the pa=
per is nice in the sense
> that it allows the CPPN to express one type of c=
onnection without being
> forced to express another at the same time - that=
's what the band pruning
> achieves. Otherwise you'd get points chosen on b=
oth sides of a sharp
> border, forcing connections often to be chosen in pa=
irs (which seems an
> undesirable tendency).
> > >
> > > ken
> > >
> > >
> =
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@> wrote:
> > > >
> =
> > > I am puzzled by the result of band pruning in Figure 3: Example
> poi=
nt selection in two dimensions, from Evolving the Placement and Density
> o=
f Neurons in the HyperNEAT Substrate. It seems like the information
> inher=
ent in the image should include points along the black-white edge of
> the =
outer black region, but band pruning removes them all. The figure
> explain=
s "In effect, the CPPN speaks a language through its pattern that
> denotes=
 exactly which weights within the hypercube should be expressed." I
> am cu=
rious why "language" is used here.
> > > >
> > > > My goal is to add iterat=
ed ES-HyperNEAT to the C++ version at
> https://github.com/MisterTea/HyperN=
EAT. I am presently a hobbyist (my
> profession is embedded software engine=
ering) but considering to someday
> pursue a PhD involving HyperNEAT, etc.
=
> > > >
> > > > Thanks,
> > > > Tony Wilson
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
>  
>

--14dae9340c718302c704bd8361f9

Hi Tony,<div><br></div><div>Since you still define the position of the inpu=
t nodes and ES-HyperNEAT starts to discover the hidden nodes from there, yo=
u can still have input nodes at the borders. The one thing that's a lit=
tle=C2=A0trickier=C2=A0is getting hidden nodes directly at the boundaries (=
e.g. x=3D-1), because the location of a new hidden node is determined by th=
e center of quadtree square. The initial square used for the quadtree extra=
ction=C2=A0</div>
<div>normally=C2=A0spans the space from (-1, -1) to (1, 1=
), so=C2=A0similarly=C2=A0to what you suggested you could have an initial s=
quare that e.g. spans the space from (-1.2, -1.2) =C2=A0to (1.2, 1.2). This=
 way you could have hidden nodes expressed closer to e.g. x=3D-1.=C2=A0Howe=
ver, I'm not sure how important it is to be able to express hidden node=
s at exactly those locations and I believe it probably doesn't hurt the=
 algorithm that the hidden node might be expressed at a slightly different =
location (e.g. -0.9).</div>
<div><br></div><div>One thing that would be dif=
ferent=C2=A0from previously published ES-HyperNEAT experiments=C2=A0with a =
domain like Go is that you have a grid-like setup of input nodes=C2=A0inste=
ad of having inputs in a horizontal line (e.g. at y=3D-1). A typical setup =
for HyperNEAT for these kind of domains uses multiple different two-dimensi=
onal layers of neurons. An example can be found in this paper:=C2=A0<a href=
=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/gauci_ppsn10.pdf">http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/papers/gauci_ppsn10.pdf</a>=C2=A0(figure 1)</div>
<div><br></div><div>For=
 ES-HyperNEAT it would probably make sense to give the CPPN an additional i=
nput (instead of an additional output as in the HyperNEAT paper), which wou=
ld determine if you query connections from the input to the hidden layer or=
 from the hidden layer to the output layer.=C2=A0This way the ES-HyperNEAT =
algorithm could just be applied to the one weight output pattern, as in the=
 previously published experiments.=C2=A0</div>
<div><br></div><div>Please l=
et me know if this helps or if you have any other questions about ES-HyperN=
EAT. We will also release an updated version of ES-HyperNEAT implemented in=
 C# soon.</div><div><br></div><div>Sebastian</div>

     <p><br>
On second thought, if I'm evolving a 5x5 board evaluator a=
nd treat it as if it is 7x7, then band pruning will remove the excess edge =
nodes without automatically clobbering the 5x5 edge nodes.  I wonder how ef=
fective that would be.<br>

<br>
Tony</p><div class=3D"im"><br>

ints that are enclosed by at least two neighbors on opposite sides (e.g. le=
ft and right) with di fferent CPPN activation levels"<br>

r>

o_ neighbors of different level on opposite sides, so I believe that is the=
 reason they are pruned away.  However, it's possible that I'm misu=
nderstanding the question, in which case please let me know.<br>

> >=
 <br>
> > Regarding the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a lang=
uage through its pattern," this idea conveys that of course there is m=
ore than one way to interpret the patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose=
, and any such method of interpretation is a kind of language.  In other wo=
rds, there might be other perfectly legitimate ways of deciding which conne=
ctions to express from an infinite-resolution pattern that are different fr=
om the method in the paper (i.e. those would be different "languages&q=
uot; for the CPPN to express what it wants).  <br>

> > <br>
> &gt=
; However, the "language" suggested in the paper is nice in the s=
ense that it allows the CPPN to express one type of connection without bein=
g forced to express another at the same time - that's what the band pru=
ning achieves.  Otherwise you'd get points chosen on both sides of a sh=
arp border, forcing connections often to be chosen in pairs (which seems an=
 undesirable tendency).<br>
